newsitem.title: GERMANY: INSTANT VIEW -German labour data disappoints.
newsitem.headline: INSTANT VIEW -German labour data disappoints.

text.p: Following are comments from economists to German September unemployment data that were released on Tuesday.

The number of people out of work in all of Germany rose 39,000 to 3.991 million on a seasonally-adjusted basis in September. The unemployment rate, based on unadjusted data, eased slightly to 10.1 percent from 10.2 percent in August.
Rainer Veit, senior economist, Deutsche Bank:
"This is certainly a setback for hopes that the economy is gaining momentum," Veit told Reuters Financial Television.
"I don't suppose today's labour market data will lead to any changes in forex rates. The Bundesbank can live with today's foreign exchange rates."
Shanda Persaud, San Paulo Bank, London:
"German exports are up and domestic orders are down and that's coming through in these unemployment figures," she said.
"We wont nececessarily see an increase in the balance in favour of a repo cut. But it could make the Bundesbank think more about the direction of the economy."

"Its definitely a disappointment, and any hope that the recent positive economic indicators that we've seen during the last few months will already have an impact on the labour market have been proven false," he said.
"It looks like companies are still very reluctant to hire new people, possibly also because of the insecurity with relation to changes in labour legislation, for example, in sick-pay."

Asked whether the data showed that economic growth was faltering, Haffner said "Other economic indicators do not point in that direction yet. I do not believe that this single number is a sufficiently well-founded reason for the Bundesbank to think seriously again about lowering interest rates."
